Award.AwardTitle: EAR-PF: Structure of the North American craton from joint inversion of receiver functions, body waves, and surface waves
Award.AbstractNarration:
Robert Porritt has been granted an NSF Earth Sciences postdoctoral fellowship to carry out a research and education plan at the University of Southern California. He will study the internal structure of the North American Craton through seismic imaging methods. The project aims to delineate sub-horizontal layering in the continental lithosphere, which would indicate formation of the craton by successively stacking oceanic lithosphere. To accomplish this, receiver function, surface wave, and body wave imaging techniques will be brought together in a consistent joint inversion framework. The three methods have complementary sensitivities such that where one method is ambiguous; the other two provide unique constraints. Together, the joint inversion will constrain velocity structure and highlight internal layers. The project will start by imaging the Hudson's Bay region at the heart of the craton and then will expand to include the contiguous United States by utilizing the USArray of EarthScope.

The mechanism of creating long standing continental crust is an outstanding fundamental question in earth science. Seismic wavespeed models provide physical constraints necessary for placing geochemical observations, initiating geodynamic models, and can be compared with other geophysical observations. To facilitate this cross-disciplinary work, the models generated through this work will be readily available to the public and other researchers. The education arm of the fellowship contains elements at both the graduate and undergraduate level. Competitive proposals for interns will be submitted to the IRIS Internship and SCEC Internship programs to pair enthusiastic undergraduates with the project. Additional undergraduate outreach will include interaction with a USC field course in Morocco. The graduate level component is through the USArray short course, which brings together graduate students from across the globe to spread ideas and best practices for seismic data processing with the insurmountable dataset being generated by EarthScope and its USArray component.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has been valuable for the growth of young researchers and has helped improve our understanding of cratonic and deformational structure. Through this fellowship, we've mentored two graduate students at USC, mentored an IRIS Intern who is now pursuing a PhD, and taught at the IRIS-USArray Data Processing Short Course at Northwestern University in 2013 and 2014. The PI, a postdoctoral researcher funded through this fellowship, has grown significantly as a researcher and this has led to a visiting researcher position at Kobe University in the summer of 2015 and an offer for continuing as a postdoctoral researcher.

During this project we’ve published two papers and generated enough research material for three more papers. The main paper of this project was published in Geology, Geophysics, Geosystems focusing on the structure of Hudson Bay. In this study we combined surface wave phase velocity information with P to S receiver functions, a method of isolating seismic velocity contrasts at depth, to estimate the mean shear velocity in the region. We then used that mean shear velocity model while computing S to P and SKS to P receiver functions (SRF). The SRF were gathered to form a common conversion point volume which is a three-dimensional model of vertical velocity contrast as a function of location within the Earth. From this model we estimated the depth to Lithosphere-Asthenosphere Boundary, which represents the base of the tectonic plate. We also identified a stronger than usual conversion at this boundary indicating a relatively high temperature upper asthenosphere. We inferred this high temperature reflects the thermal blanketing effect caused by trapped heat under the lithosphere. From this model, we also observed features associated with the Great Meteor Hotspot and the Grenville Orogeny.

            Additionally, during the time at USC, we’ve used the opportunity to foster other collaborations. This has resulted in a paper with Prof. Becker at USC and Prof. Monsalve from Colombia investigating seismic anisotropy in Colombia. This work has shown a highly complex anisotropy pattern at the northern end of the Andes. We’ve also used this funding to help write receiver function findings observed near an unusually deep earthquake in Japan and investigating time-varying receiver functions around the 2011 Tohoku-Oki earthquake. Finally, the collaboration at USC between PI Porritt and Prof. Miller is continuing as we investigate seismic velocity structure in the Banda Arc. For this collaboration we’ve generated a preliminary seismic velocity model and are currently preparing a manuscript for submission.

            The two graduate students being mentored at USC are using seismic imaging methods to address significantly different questions at different scales. One student is using body wave tomography and shear-wave splitting to investigate the mantle velocity structure and mantle flow around two highly curved subduction zones in the Caribbean and the Banda Arc. The other student is using receiver functions and ambient noise to investigate the lower crustal structure in the Parkfield region. Her focus is on understanding the stress in the region and its relation to seismicity. Over the summer of 2014, we mentored an IRIS intern at USC. During the summer she investigated the structure around the Wyoming craton with P to S receiver functions and SRF. She presented this work at the fall 2014 AGU meeting and is currently pursuing a PhD at the University of Washington.
